posts.name: Anupam Chandra
posts.cooked: Can we visualize outliers in scatter plot Tools in Data Science

posts.name: DNarendran
posts.cooked:
Scatter plot shows relationship between 2 variables. Its used to visualize correlation. Box plot shows outliers. To identify outliers, you need IQR as well, which box plot depicts.

Agreed, but can the scatter plot help you visually identify outliers in a dataset - yes or no

posts.name: DNarendran
posts.cooked:
Scatter plots need 2 variables. How will you use a scatter plot to identify outliers in one variable?

Agreed, but i the question it is not mentioned if it is one variable or more than one variable.
can the scatter plot help you visually identify outliers in a dataset - yes or no

posts.name: Anupam Chandra
posts.cooked:
You cannot identify outliers with precision in a scatter plot as you need the IQR or something similar for that, which a scatter plot doesn’t provide.

It will only be a visual approximation, which would be more useful as an EDA exercise.

posts.name: Carlton D'Silva
posts.cooked:
Scatter plots are often used in the real world for bivariate outlier detection through the use of z scores, residuals in regression analysis, elliptic envelope (multivariate normal distribution). All these are precise mathematical tools that can be visually mapped on the scatter plot to detect outliers.

Resolution : Q444 will be given marks for both box plots as well as scatter plots being marked as the correct answer.

posts.name: Anupam Chandra
posts.cooked:
Hello @carlton

Regarding the question on the use of bar charts, I (and a lot of other people creating business presentations) have extensively used bar charts to compare two or more variables. For e.g., comparing the revenue of this year vs last year, broken down by quarter. Same for profits, margins, no. of people in the organization and stuff like that.

image1080×363 85.6 KB

Kindly share your views.

posts.name: Carlton D'Silva
posts.cooked:
I have been told by instructors and academics who are much more qualified than me that the improper use of graphs is rife in business presentations and that includes using bar charts for comparing two or more variables. The improper use of charts does not mean that they are the appropriate tool for the job. Hence for this question the correct answer is categorical data.

People in the statistics department (and the business department) take particular umbrage to the improper use of graphs. It’s one of their pet peeves.

A good analogy is that we can use a spanner to hit a nail. Does not mean its the best tool to hit a nail. In this question it does use the qualifier best and its hard to argue for other choices when categorical data is one of the choices, because that is in fact the best use of a bar chart.

posts.name: Anupam Chandra
posts.cooked:
If 95% of the people are using this approach, perhaps it is time for the statisticians and academicians to update their approach and align themselves with the ground reality (aka real world) .

Also FYI, there isn’t a single person in any business department who doesn’t use bar charts according to the way I have described. In fact, one would be hard pressed to find other ways in which bar charts are used as a % of usage.

You can ask @s.anand about this if you want. I’m sure he has come across many presentations which use bar charts in his career.
